title: Doc Martin, episode 2 review: this grumpy GP's diagnostic skills are unlike any other
text:
Usually in medical dramas obscure diseases, and the complex business of diagnosing them, exist primarily to test medical staff to the limits. But it doesn’t work that way in Doc Martin (ITV), which upends the principle and employs the most recondite conditions imaginable, and Dr Martin Ellingham’s (Martin Clunes) ability to diagnose them instantly, as a kind of signpost reminder that cantankerousness and genius can work hand in hand.

Last night’s episode saw our grumpy GP attending to a man collapsed in a goat shed and announcing within seconds that the quivering chap was suffering from “Guillaume Barré neuropathology – a very rare and very serious nerve condition”. Wow, such sagacity has got...
description: Usually in medical dramas obscure diseases, and the complex business of diagnosing them, exist primarily to test medical staff to the limits.
